newsitem.title: PAKISTAN: CRICKET-HASAN RAZA MISSES SCHOOL TO MAKE TEST MATCH HISTORY.
newsitem.headline: CRICKET-HASAN RAZA MISSES SCHOOL TO MAKE TEST MATCH HISTORY.

text.p: In a story straight
out of a boy's comic, Pakistan's Hasan Raza stepped into test
cricket on Thursday at the tender age of 14 years and 227 days
to steer his side out of a tricky situation.
The Karachi-born schoolboy easily beat the previous record
for the youngest test player, set by Pakistan's current manager
Pakistan's Mushtaq Muhammad, who was 15 years and 124 days on
his debut against West Indies in 1958-59.
Although not exactly staring defeat in the face, Pakistan
had made an uncertain start to their innings to be 67 for three
in reply to Zimbabwe's first innings 133 on the opening day of
the second test.
Enter Hasan Raza, and any fears of a collapse disappeared.
He promptly played an exquisite late cut off leg-spinner
Paul Strang and went on to hit three more boundaries in an
unbeaten 20 by the close as he and opener Saeed Anwar shared in
an unbroken 47-run partnership for the fourth wicket which took
Pakistan to only 19 runs behind Zimbabwe.
"I am just thrilled to be playing for my country. It is
indeed a great honour, more so when I have become the youngest
test cricketer," Raza said shyly after stumps were drawn.
He said he felt he had improved his chances for selection
after scoring heavily in Pakistan's Under-19 championship and
after making 58 for a Combined XI against Zimbabwe.
Raza was introduced to the game as a seven-year-old when he
joined Karachi's Nazimabad Sports Club, and came to prominence
when he played in the Under-15 World Cup in England earlier this
year.
"I enjoyed playing in England and especially the final
against India at Lords," the slender batsman told Reuters.
Raza, a ninth class student at the Government Boys Secondary
School, Karachi, showed his talent in the Under-19 Championship,
in which he scored 791 runs, including four centuries.
His 134 against Lahore in the final attracted the attention
of the national selectors, who picked Raza for the opening match
of Zimbabwe's tour. He went to the wicket with the Combined XI
in deep trouble at 110 for four, but soon transformed the game
with a lusty 58 from 55 balls, including two sixes and five
fours.
Raza, the son of a businessman who has six children, says
education, not cricket, must take priority at the moment.
"Education is very imperative. I know I can't play cricket
all my life and that is why I want to complete my education
before turning to cricket on a whole-time basis," he said.
"My great ambition is to play the next World Cup in England
in 1999 and by that time I should have gained more experience."
By that time he will be a hardened veteran of 17.
Raza said he had modelled his hard-hitting style on that of
compatriot Basit Ali, now out of form and out of the test side.
